WorkItem.ClosedComment: A fix has been checked in and will be visible in an upcoming release.
WorkItem.Description:
I really like the new "tsc --watch" functionality - it massively speeds up my compile times and makes development for the browser much more natural - thanks.

The issue I am having is that while there is a handy banner that tells you when a compilation starts (including a super-handy timestamp), there is presently no way of knowing when a compilation is done.

This makes it much harder to integrate "tsc --watch" into ones development workflow.

For example:

I  want emacs M-x compile to show the errors from the last compilation.  I have written a python script to extract this from the compilation log - but not knowing whether the compilation is done means I have to do funny guessing and timeouts.

I want to be able to just click refresh in the browser after editing the program and have it just run as if it was straight JS - but go to an error page instead of the typescript compilation failed.  My plan was to have the browser fetch the compilation log, grab out the last compilation etc - but again I am stymied by no reliable way of knowing that a compilation is done.

A simple extra newline (or any other unique marker) at the end of each "tsc -w" compilation batch would make me very happy.

- Thanks

David

-
WorkItem.Summary: Please add newline after compilation results in watch mode.

Comments.Message: Can you have emacs delete the JS file on save, that way you will get a 404 in the browser until the compilation is done?
